For Marie loue, þat mayden freo,
O god and persones þreo,
Arst ȝif him wan and wrake!«
»Douȝtur«, he seide, »beo now stille,
Þow schalt neuere be weddet him tille
For bost, þat he con make;
I schal him seende such wordes to seyn, 70 C. word statt wordes.
Þat al his þouȝt schal torne to veyn,
For þou hast him forsake.«
Bi þeos same messagers,
Þat comeþ from þe soudan fers,
Þeos wordes to him he sent,
Heo nolde not leeuen on his maneers, 76 C. wolde statt nolde.
To god heo made hire preyers,
Þat lord omnipotent,
& bad him take anoþer þouȝt,
For hire ne scholde he wedde nouht,
For gold, seluer ne rent.
Whon þe messagers þis herde seyn,
Soone þei tornede hem aȝeyn
And to þe soudan went.
Þe soudan sat at his des,
Iserued of his furste mes,
Þei comen in to þe halle;
To fore þe prince proud in pres
Heore tale þei tolden, wiþ outen lees,
And on heore kneos gunne falle
And seide: »Sire, þe kyng of Tars 91 C. kyn statt kyng.
Of wikked wordes nis not scars,
Heþene hound he doþ þe calle;
And er his douȝter be ȝiue þe tille,
Þyn herte blod he wol spille
And þi barouns alle.«
Whon þe soudan þis I-herde,
As a wod mon he ferde,
His robe he rente adoun; 99 C. robes statt robe.
He tar þe her of hed and berd
And seide, he wolde hir winne wiþ swerd, 101 V. hir.
Beo his lord, seynt Mahoun.
Þe table adoun riht he smot
In to þe flore foot hot,
He lokede as a wylde lyon;
Al þat he hitte, he smot doun riht,
Boþe sergaunt and kniht,
Erl and eke baroun.
So he ferde, forsoþe a-pliht,
Al a day and al a niht,
Þat no mon miht hym chaste; 111 V. mihti.
A morwen, whon hit was day liht,
He sent his messagers ful riht
After his barouns in haste,
»Lordynges,« he seiþ, »what to rede?
Me is don a gret misdede:
Of Taars þe cristene kyng,
I bed him boþe lond and lede,
To haue his douhter in worþli wede
And spouse hire wiþ my ryng;
And he seide, wiþ outen fayle,
Arst he wolde me sle in batayle
And mony a gret lordyng;
Ac, sertes, he schal be forswore
Or to wroþehele þan he was bore, 125 þan V. und C. þat.
Bote he hit þer to bring.
Þerfore, lordinges, i haue aftur ow sent,
For to come to my parliment,
To wite of ȝow counsayle.«
And alle onswerde wiþ good entent,
Þei wolde be at his comaundement,
Wiþ outen eny fayle.
And whon þei were alle at his heste.
Þe soudan made a wel gret feste
For loue of his batayle.
Þe soudan gederet an ost vnryde,
Wiþ Sarazins of muchel pryde
Þe kyng of Tars to assayle.
Whon þe kyng hit herde þat tyde,
He sente aboute on vche a syde,
Alle þat he mihte of-seende;
Gret werre þo bigon to wake, 142 wake] so C.; wrake V.
For þe mariage ne moste be take
Of þat mayden heende.
Batayle þei sette vppon a day
Wiþ inne þe þridde day of May,
No lengor nolde þei leende.
Þe soudan com wiþ gret power,
Wiþ helm briht and feir baneer,
Vppon þat kyng to wende.
Þe soudan ladde an huge ost
And com wiþ muche pruyde & bost
Wiþ þe kyng of Tars to fihte;
Wiþ hym mony a Sarazin feer;
Alle þe feldes feor and neer
Of helmes leomede lihte.
Þe kyng of Tars com also,
Þe soudan batayle for to do,
Wiþ mony a cristene kniht.
Eyþer ost gon oþur assayle;
Þer bigon a strong batayle,
Þat grislych was of siht,
Þreo heþene aȝein twey cristene men,
And falde hem doun in þe fen,
Wiþ wepnes stif and goode;
Þe steorne Sarazins in þat fiht
Slowe vr cristene men doun riht,
Þei fouhte, as heo weore woode.
Þe soudan ost in þat stounde
Feolde þe cristene to þe grounde,
Mony a freoly foode.
Þe Sarazins, wiþ outen fayle,
Þe cristene culde in þat batayle,
Nas non, þat hem wiþ-stode.
Whon þe kyng of Tars sauh þat siht, 175 C. Tar statt of Tars.
Wod he was for wraþthorn;e, apliht,
In hond he hente a spere,
And to þe soudan he rod ful riht:
Wiþ a dunt of muche miht
Adoun he gon him bere.
Þe soudan neiȝ he hedde islawe,
But þritti þousent of heþene lawe
Coomen him for to were
And brouȝten him aȝeyn vppon his steede
And holpe him wel in þat nede,
Þat no mon mihte him dere.
Whon he was brouht vppon his stede,
He sprong as sparkle doþ of glede
For wraþthorn;e and for envye;
Alle þat he hutte, he made hem blede,
He ferde, as he wolde a-wede;
»Mahoun, help!« he gan crye.
Mony an helm þer was vn-weued
And mony a bacinet to-cleued
And sadeles mony emptye;
Men mihte se vppon þe feld
Moni a kniht ded vnder scheld
Of þe cristene cumpaignye.
Whon þe kyng of Tars sauȝ hem so ryde,
No lengor þere he nolde abyde,
Bote fleyh to his oune cite;
Þe Sarazins þat ilke tyde
Slouȝ adoun bi vche a syde
Vr cristene folk so fre.
Þe Sarazins Þat tyme, saunz fayle, 205 C. tyde statt tyme.
Slowe vr cristene in batayle,
Þat reuþe hit was to se,
And on þe morwe for heore sake
Truwes þei gunne to gidere take
A moneþ and dayes þre.
As þe king of Tars sat in his halle,
He made ful gret deol wiþ alle
For þe folk, þat he hedde ilore.
His douhter com in riche palle,
On kneos heo gon biforen him falle
And seide wiþ syking sore:
»Fader,« heo seide, »let me beo his wyf,
Þat þer be no more strif,
Þen haþ ben her bi fore;
For me haþ be muche folk schent,
Slawen & morþred and to-rent,
Allas, þat i was bore!
Fader, i chulle him serue at wille,
Erli and late, loude and stille,
And leeuen on god almiht;
Bote hit be so, he wol þe spille
And al þi londes take hym tille
In batayle and in fiht.
Certes, i nul no lengor drye,
Þat cristene men schul for me dye,
Þorw grace of god almiht.«
Þen was þe kyng of Tars ful wo; 232 C. Tar statt Tars.
Anon he onswerde þo
To his douhter briht:
»Douhter,« he seide, »blessed þou be
Of god, þat sit in trinite,
Þe tyme þat þou were bore,
Þat þou wolt saue þi moder and me;
Þi preyere now i graunte þe,
Of þat þou bede be fore.«
»Fader,« heo seide, »par charite
And for Crist in trinite,
Blyue þat ich weore þore,
Ar eny more serwe arere,
Þat ȝe ne my moder dere
For me beo nouȝt for-lore.
Þe kyng þo, wiþ good entent,
In to his chaumbre haþ isent
Aftur his qween so hende;
Whon heo was comen in present,
»Dame,« he seide, »vr douȝter haþ ment, 251 C. munt statt ment.
To þe soudan for to weende:
Dame,« he seide, »counseyle me,
Her beoþ no mo, bote we þre,
Icomen of cristene kende.«
Þe qween onswerde, wiþ outen fayle:
»Þer to schal i neuere counseyle,
Vre douhter for to schende.«
Þenne was þe douȝter wo,
Merci heo criȝede hire moder þo
Wiþ a reuþful steuene:
»Moder, hit nis not longe a-gon,
Þat þer were for me slon
Þreo þousent men and seuene;
And, certes, i nul no lengor drye,
Þat cristen men schul for me dye,
Þorwȝ grace of god in heuene.«
Weore þei wel, weore þei wroþe,
Þe douȝter dude ouercome hem boþe
Beo riht reson and euene.
Whon þei weoren þus a ton,
Messageres he sente a-non
To þe proude soudan,
To make frendes, þat weore fon,
No mo folk þei wolde slon,
His douȝter he graunted him þan.
Whon þe messagers þus herde seyn,
Smartliche þei tornede aȝeyn
To þe soudan swart and wan.
Whon he herde heore lettres rad,
Þen was he boþe bliþe and glad
And murie as eny man
And seide: »I chul ben at his wille,
Erly and late, loude and stille,
And help him at his neode;
No mo folk nul i now spille.«
Þe kyng anon he sende tille
And þonkede him of þat dede.
Þe kyng & qwene in chaumbre were þo
In care and serwe and muche wo,
In stori as we rede.
Wel hem was wiþ oute les, 292 C. hym statt hem.
Þat þe soudan wolde make pes
Wiþ cristen felaurede.
Þis fel in mid-somer tyde,
Þe soudan nolde no lengor byde,
To þe kyng of Tars he sent
Wiþ Sarazins & wiþ muche pryde
Wiþ mony a juwel, is nouȝt to huyde,
To make hym a present.
Forþ þei went þat ilke tyde,
To þe kyng of Tars þei gan ryde,
Þat was boþe freo and gent;
Þei welcomed þe messagere.
Of gret reuþe ȝe may here,
Whon þei to chaumbre went.
In chaumbre kyng & qwene was þo
In serwe & care & muche wo
For heore douȝter hende.
Heor douȝter com bi fore hem bo 310 wende V.; in bo umgeändert C.
And bad hem bi hire counseil do, 311 C. hat bi ausgelassen.
To saue cristene kende.
Þe douȝter þer wiþ wordes stille
Brouȝt hem boþe in beter wille
And in to halle gunne wende
And welcomede þe messagers,
Þat come from þe soudan fers,
Wiþ wordes feire and hende.
Þen seide þe qwene after þan:
»Hou fareþ ȝor lord, þe soudan,
Þat is so noble a kniht?«
Þe messagers onswere gan:
»He fareþ as wel as eny man
And is ȝor frend, apliht.«
Þe qween onswerde wiþ mylde mod
To þe messagers, þer þei stod,
And swor þenne a-non riht:
»Ich fouche saaf on him my blod,
To him heo nis not to good,
Þauȝ heo weore ten so briht.«
Þe messagers weore glad and blyþe,
Wiþ knihtes fele & stedes styþe
Þei brouhte hire to chare; 333 C. to hir statt hire to.
Þe kyng & qwen weoren vnbliþe,
Heore serwe couþe no mon kiþe,
To seon hire from hem fare;
Þei seȝe, hit mihte non oþer go;
Þe kyng and þe qwene also,
Þei custe heore douhter þare,
Bi-tauȝten hire god for euer mo;
Hem self aȝeyn þei tornede þo,
Of blisse þei weore al bare.
Nou lete we of þat mournyng
And speke we of þat maiden ȝing,
To þe soudan heo is i-fare.
He come wiþ mony an heiȝ lordyng,
For to welcome þat swete þing,
Þer heo com in hire chare;
He custe hire wel mony a siþe,
His joye couþe no mon kiþe,
A wei was al hire care. 351 C. his statt hire.
In to chaumbre heo was led
Wiþ riche cloþes heo was clede,
Heþene as þauȝ heo ware.
Þe soudan, þer he sat in halle,
He comaundede his knihtes alle,
Þat maiden for to fette;
In cloþ of riche purpel palle 358 C. cloþing statt cloþ.
And on hire hed a comeli calle,
Bi þe soudan heo was sette.
Vn-semely was hit for to se,
Heo, þat was so briht of ble,
To habbe so foul a mette; 363 C. haue statt habbe.
Þauȝ heo made merþe and solas,
Þe serwe, at hire herte was,
Ne mihte no mon hit lette.
Whon hit com to þe niht,
Leue heo tok, þat buirde briht,
To chaumbre for to wende;
Wiþ hire wente moni an heþen kniht,
A riche bed þer was idiht
For þat maiden hende.
Whon hit was al redi wrouht,
Þe soudan nolde þerin come nouht,
For fo ne for frende;
But he mihte make þat may
To leeuen vppon his false lay,
Þat com of cristene kende.
Ful loþ were a cristene mon,
To ligge bi an heþene wommon,
Þat leeuede on false lawe;
And as loþ was þulke soudan,
Þulke maiden for to tan,
As ich fynde in my sawe.
Þe soudan went to bedde al prest,
Knihtes & ladyes token heore rest,
Folk heo gonne wiþ-drawe;
Þe mayden no þing ne slepe,
But al niht lay and wepe,
Forte þat day gon dawe.
And as heo fel a slepe þore, 391 Am rande: Sompniū.
Hir þhouȝte, þer stod hire bifore
An hundred houndes blake
And borken on hire, lasse and more;
On þer was, þat greued hire sore,
Awei he wolde hire take;
Ac heo ne durste him not smyte,
For drede, leste he wolde hire byte,
Such maystries he gon make;
And as heo wolde awei fle,
Hir þhouȝte, þer stode deueles þre,
Al brennyng as a drake.
So gryslich þei were wrought,
Vche of hem a swerd brought
And mad hire afert so sore; 405 C. aferd statt afert.
On Jesu Crist was al hire þouht,
Þerfore þei mihte hire harme nouht,
Nouþer lasse ne more.
Fro þe fendes heo was delyuered sound,
But atte laste þer com an hound
Wiþ brode brouwes and hore;
Almost he hedde hire adoun,
But þorw Cristes passioun
Heo was isaued þore.
Ȝit þhouȝte hire more, wiþ oute lesyng, 415 C. outen statt oute.
As heo lay in hire sweuenyng,
Selcouþ hit is to rede,
þe blake hound, þat hire was folewyng,
þorw þe miht of heuene kyng
To hire spac in monhede,
In whit armuyre as a kniht,
And seide to hire: »My swete wiȝt,
Ne dar þe no þing drede
Of Tirmagaunt ne of Mahoun;
þe lord, þat soffrede passioun,
þe schal helpe at nede.«
Whon þe mayde was awaked,
Hire flesch, i-wis, was al aquaked
For drede of hire sweuenynge;
On hire bed heo sat al naked,
To Jesu Crist hire mone heo maked,
Al-mihtful heuene kynge,
As wis as he hire deore bouhte,
þat hire sweuene, þat heo þouhte,
Scholde torne to good endynge.
Whon þe maiden arysen was,
A-non þe soudan of Damas, 437 C. Domas statt Damas.
In to his temple he let hire bringe
And seide to þat feire may:
»þou most leeuen vppon my lay
And knele her adoun;
Forsake þou most þi false lay,
þat þou hast leued on mony a day,
And leeuen on sire Mahoun;
Certes, but þou wolt to so,
þi fader & moder i chulle slo:
Bi Jouin and Plotoun, 447 C. platoun statt Plotoun.
Bi Mahoun and bi Tirmagaunt,
No mon schal be heore waraunt,
Emperour ne kyng wiþ croun.«
þe mayden onswerde wiþ glad chere
To þe soudan, as ȝe may heere:
«Sire, i nul þe no þing greue:
Tel me, whuch is ȝoure maneere,
So schal i make my preyere,
And on ȝor goddes leeue!
To Tirmagaunt i chul me take
And Jesu Crist i chul forsake
þat made Adam and Eue,
And serue þe, sire, at þi wille,
Erli and late, loud and stille,
A morwe and eke an eue.«
þenne was þe soudan glad and bliþe,
Mahoun he þonkede feole siþe,
þat heo was so bi-knowe.
His joyes couþe no mon kiþe,
He bad hire go aboute swiþe
And cusse his goddes arowe.
Furst he custe Appolin, 469 C. heo, o nachgetragen, statt he.
Astrot and sire Jouin,
For drede of worldes awe.
In þe temple, whil heo was þer,
Of Mahoun and Jubiter,
þer heo lernde hire lawe.
Whon þat heo hire lawes couþe,
Heo seide hem openly wiþ mouþe,
Ac Crist for-ȝat heo nouht;
Wher heo weore bi norþ or souþe,
Nas munstral non wiþ harpe ne crouþe,
þat ones mihte chaunge hire þouȝt.
Euere wende þe soudan niht and day,
Heo hedde ileeued on his lay,
And ȝit he was bi-cauht;
Whon heo was hire self al one,
To Jesu Crist heo made hire mone,
þat al þis world haþ wrouht.
Þe soudan for hire loue þat tyde
Let criȝe in his lond bi vch a syde, 488 C. in statt bi.
A turnament to take;
þe strengest, þat mihte on hors ryde,
He dubbede hem wiþ muche pryde,
And knihtes he let hem make.
Trompors gunne heore bemes blowe,
þe knihtes riden out on a rowe
On stedes white and blake.
Anon riht also swiþe
Stronge men gon maystries kiþe
For þat maidenes sake.
Þe mayden and þe soudan
In a tour þei leȝen þan
Þe turnament to bi-holde;
Whon þe turnament bi-gon,
Þer was semblet mony a mon
Of Sarazins stout and bolde.
Heo leyden on, as heo weore wode, 505 C. a statt as.
Wiþ swerdes and wiþ maces goode,
Knihtes ȝonge and olde.
So þei fouȝte wiþ egre mood,
Of heore bodies ran þe blod,
In tale as hit is tolde.
Mony an helm þer was vn-weued
And bacinettes al to-dreued
And knihtes icast to grounde,
And summe pleyed of þe heued,
And summe heore scolles icleued,
Wiþ serwe þei weore vn-sounde.
So laste þe turnement, apliht, 517 C. þt statt þe.
Fro þe morwe to þe niht,
Þer ȝeuen was moni a wounde;
A morwe þe soudan wedded þat may
In þe maner of his lay,
In stori as hit is founde.
Þe soudan and þat ladi fre,
Þei weore to gedere but moneþus þre,
Þat heo ne was grete wiþ childe;
Heo gon to chaunge al hire bleo,
Þe soudan self hit gon iseo,
Joly he wax and wylde.
Þen was þe ladi swiþe wo,
Jesu heo bi-souȝte þo,
From schome he scholde hire schilde.
And bi þe fourti wikes ende
Heo was delyuered out of beende 533 C. delyuer statt delyuered.
Þorw help of Marie mylde.
And whon þe child was ibore,
Wo was þe midwyf þer fore
For lymes hedde hit non,
But as a roonde of flesch icore,
In chaumbre lay hire bi fore,
Wiþ outen blod or bon.
Þe ladi was wo, as heo wolde dye,
Hit hedde nouþer neose nor eiȝe,
But lay stille as a ston.
Þe soudan com þat ilke tyde
And wiþ his wyf he gon to chyde,
Þat wo was hire bi-gon.
»Sertes, dame, i sei þe bi fore,
Aȝeyn my goddes þou art forswore,
Bi riht reson i preue.
Þerfore þis child, þat is ibore,
Lyf and lyme hit is forlore,
Þorw þi false by-leeue;
Þou leeuest not riht a-fyn
On Astrot ne on Jouyn,
On morwe ne on eue,
On Mahoun ne on Tirmagaunt,
Þerfore iloren is þis luytel faunt,
No wonder, þauȝ me greue.«
Þen þe ladi was ful wo,
Anon onswerde þe soudan þo:
»Sire, let be þi þouht;
Þe child, þat we haue to gedere two,
For þi bi-leeue hit fareþ so,
Bi him, þat me haþ wrouht:
Tak hit vp wel sone a-non
And to ȝor temple þer wiþ ȝe gon,
And loke, ȝe lette hit nouht;
And preye þi goddes alle ifeere,
As þow art hem boþe lef and dere,
To lyue þat hit beo brouht.
And ȝif Mahoun and Jouin con
Make hit iformed aftur mon
Wiþ lyf and limes ariht,
Be him, þat al þis world wan,
I chul bi-leeue vppon hem þan,
Þat þei beoþ of miht;
And but þei hit conne to lyue bringe,
On hem by-leeue i nul no þinge,
Nouþer bi day nor niht.«
Þe child he tok vp a-non,
In to his temple he con gon,
Bi fore his godes hit diht.
Vppon his auter he con hit leyn
And heold vp his hondes tweyn,
Þe mountaunce of fyue myle.
»A, mihtful Mahoun,« he gan sayn,
»And Tirmagaunt so ful of mayn,
In ȝow nas neuer gyle;
Astrot and sire Jouin,
Tirmagaunt and Appolin,
Now help in þis peryle!«
Ofte he criȝede and ofte he ros
So longe, þat he wox al hos,
And al he loste his while.
Whon he hedde al to gedere ipreyd
And al, þat euere he couþe, iseyd,
Hit lay as stille as ston;
He sturte him vp in a breyd,
In his herte sore atrayȝed,
For boote com þer non.
Vppon his child he gan to calle,
Ne holpe him nouȝt his goddes alle,
Wel wo was him bi-gon.
On Tirmagaunt he gon to grede:
»On ȝow was neuere help at nede,
Fy on ow euerichon!«
He hente a staf wiþ herte grete
And al his goddes he gan to bete
And drouh hem alle adoun

Þen onswerde þat gode womman
